Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was finishing up the checklist for the overdue machine maintenance. The whirring from the factory floor was louder than usual, and I could feel the heat radiating from the machines—definitely not a good sign. I knew if I didn’t get to them soon, we could be looking at a costly breakdown. But when I glanced at my phone, I saw a message from Mark, an old acquaintance. His car had broken down on a deserted road, and he sounded desperate for help. I could almost hear the anxiety in his text, and I knew he didn’t have anyone else nearby to call. As a friend, I felt I should go to him right away, but as the repairer, I was responsible for keeping these machines running safely. My supervisor had already warned me about the risks of skipping maintenance. I stood there, phone in hand, torn between the urgent needs of a friend and the pressing demands of my job, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
